metadata.title: Thermodynamic and Transport Properties of Superconducting Mg<SUP>10</SUP>B<SUB>2</SUB>

abstracts.abstract: Transport and thermodynamic properties of a sintered pellet of the newly discovered MgB<SUB>2</SUB> superconductor have been measured to determine the characteristic critical magnetic fields and critical current densities. Both resistive transition and magnetization data give similar values of the upper critical field, H<SUB>c2</SUB>, with magnetization data giving dH<SUB>c2</SUB>/dT = 0.44 T/K at the transition temperature of T<SUB>c</SUB> = 40.2 K. Close to the transition temperature, magnetization curves are thermodynamically reversible, but at low temperatures the trapped flux can be on the order of 1 T. The value of dH<SUB>c</SUB>/dT at T<SUB>c</SUB> is estimated to be about 12 mT/K, a value similar to classical superconductors like Sn. Hence, the Ginzburg-Landau parameter κ~26. Estimates of the critical supercurrent density, J<SUB>c</SUB>, using hysteresis loops and the Bean model, give critical current densities on the order of 10<SUP>5</SUP> A/cm<SUP>2</SUP>. Hence the supercurrent coupling through the grain boundaries is comparable to intermetallics like Nb<SUB>3</SUB>Sn.
